title: 35 Pop and Jazz Albums, Shows and Festivals Coming This Fall
description: Buzzy debuts (Chappell Roan, Evian Christ) and anticipated follow-ups (Jorja Smith, yeule) are due this season.
content: After a summer dominated by blockbuster tours by Taylor Swift and Beyoncé, this fall the music business gets back to the business of releasing albums. Longstanding acts are returning with new LPs (Dolly Parton, Wilco, Usher), and long-awaited follow-ups are arriving, too (the Streets, Sampha, Nicki Minaj). Dates and lineups are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camilo Ortiz and Lenore Skenazy
title: This Simple Fix Could Help Anxious Kids
description: Overprotection may be making kids scared of the world. If so, wouldn’t the obvious solution be more independence?
content: A colleague in suburban Kentucky let his 12-year-old daughter walk two houses down to her friend’s place. At the end of the play date, the other girl’s mom walked her home, just to be safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: How Coco Gauff Can Beat Jelena Ostapenko in the U.S. Open Quarterfinals
description: Here’s what to know about the singles match between Gauff and Ostapenko, and Gauff’s return to the U.S. Open quarterfinals.
content: Coco Gauff, a 19-year-old American who has had an outstanding summer, will take on Jelena Ostapenko of Latvia in the quarterfinals of the U.S. Open on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: He’s Wanted in a 1970 Bombing. The F.B.I. Aged His Photo to Seek Tips.
description: The suspect, Leo F. Burt, has evaded capture since the anti-Vietnam War bombing at the University of Wisconsin, which was considered the largest act of domestic terrorism at the time.
content: In the more than 50 years since a bomb ripped through a mathematics center at the University of Wisconsin, killing a graduate student and injuring several others in what was considered an attack protesting the Vietnam War, the F.B.I. has received hundreds of tips about the whereabouts of one of the suspects, Leo F. Burt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: ‘Where Is the Money?’ Military Graft Becomes a Headache for Ukraine
description: The removal of the defense minister highlights the enduring challenge of corruption in Ukraine, which has emerged as a rare area of criticism of President Volodymyr Zelensky’s leadership.
content: The removal of Ukraine’s minister of defense after a flurry of reports of graft and financial mismanagement in his department underscores a pivotal challenge for President Volodymyr Zelensky’s wartime leadership: stamping out the corruption that had been widespread in Ukraine for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Anushka Patil
title: Who Is Rustem Umerov, Zelensky’s Nominee for Defense Minister of Ukraine?
description: Though a member of an opposition political party, Mr. Umerov has taken on several critical roles for the Zelensky government since the Russian invasion last year.
content: Rustem Umerov, whom President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine named as next minister of defense, will be overseeing the Ukrainian army as it is engaged in some of the fiercest fighting of the war with Russia. But his background is not military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Roy Lichtenstein and Irving Blum: They Go Way Back
description: Blum was the dealer who introduced the West Coast to Pop Art and Lichtenstein’s works in the 1960s. Now he’s showing his friend’s rarely seen sculptures.
content: The art dealer Irving Blum remembers walking into Leo Castelli’s New York gallery in 1965 and being taken by Roy Lichtenstein’s painting of a composition book, because he himself had carried one throughout grade school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: When It Comes to China, Pope Francis Keeps Criticism in Check
description: Francis called relations with Beijing “very respectful,” though few clergy or Catholics from China went to see him during a visit to Mongolia, seemingly fearing reprisals.
content: The small group of Chinese Catholics who crossed the border to see Pope Francis covered their faces for fear of reprisal. Church officials blamed the Communist government for preventing mainland China’s bishops from coming to see the pope. And diplomats said that China had watched the pope’s activities closely, and warily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: 34 Works of Fiction to Read This Fall
description: New books by Zadie Smith, Alice McDermott and Stephen King; family sagas by Ayana Mathis and Jesmyn Ward; and more.
content: When an aging poet realizes that her critical acclaim hasn’t translated to financial stability, she agrees to train a poetry A.I. program named Charlotte at a tech company’s campus in California. Over the course of a week, she grapples with questions of art, family and connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Movers See All, and They Have Thoughts on Your Relationship
description: When New York City movers clear out an apartment, they leave with a whole lot more than furniture.
content: A young woman in a U-Haul arrived in New York City nearly four years ago, ready to get settled into her new place in the West Village. She hired movers from Big Apple Moving to help her unload, Karl Osman, one of the company’s owners, recently recalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shreya Chattopadhyay and Miguel Salazar
title: 33 Nonfiction Books to Read This Fall
description: Memoirs by Barbra Streisand, Patrick Stewart, Jada Pinkett Smith; hotly anticipated books on Elon Musk and Sam Bankman-Fried; and plenty more.
content: A historian turns her eye to the country of her birth in this political history of the German Democratic Republic, which existed from 1949 to 1990. Contrary to common depictions, Hoyer presents a picture of a vibrant society that weathered intense state suppression but also enacted solidarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Paul Sonne
title: Friendly Putin-Erdogan Meeting Keeps West Guessing
description: Any notion that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey might be shifting away from his friendly ties with the Kremlin appeared to evaporate on Monday.
content: Just two months ago, many in the West thought President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey could be shifting away from what they considered his overly close relationship with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Cheung
title: Affirmative Action Is Over. Should Applicants Still Mention Their Race?
description: The first high school seniors to apply to college since the Supreme Court’s landmark decision are trying to sort through a morass of conflicting guidance.
content: On a Friday afternoon in July, 87 teenagers with name tags swinging around their necks converged in the dining hall at Nazareth University in Rochester, N.Y. They whizzed between the pizza counter and soda machines before setting their plates on tables, the chorus of the lunchroom growing louder by the minute. The students — rising high school seniors, nearly all Black or Latino — had come for a five-day workshop hosted by PeerForward, a nonprofit organization that helps promising students from low-income communities prepare to apply to college. But this year’s workshop was taking place in something of a changed world: Two weeks earlier, in a pair of high-profile cases challenging Harvard’s and the University of North Carolina’s use of affirmative action, the Supreme Court declared all race-conscious admission programs across the United States to be unlawful, and no one knew what that would mean for students like the ones sitting now in the Nazareth dining hall — least of all them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone and Zachary Woolfe
title: Classical Music and Opera This Fall: Programs, Premieres and More
description: Malcolm X at the Met. Jaap van Zweden’s farewell to the New York Philharmonic. Premieres by Kate Soper and Ted Hearne. It’s shaping up to be quite a season.
content: This is a season of transition for two of New York’s most important arts institutions. Opening with Jake Heggie’s “Dead Man Walking,” from 2000, the Metropolitan Opera will see whether fewer titles and more contemporary works (including “X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X” and “Florencia en el Amazonas”) help solve its financial problems. And Jaap van Zweden, the New York Philharmonic’s music director since 2018, starts his final year in the position with help from Yo-Yo Ma, Steve Reich and Schubert. Grand orchestras like the Chicago Symphony and Staatskapelle Berlin at Carnegie Hall; the Emerson String Quartet’s farewell; and premieres by Kate Soper and Ted Hearne are among the other highlights coming this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Malesic
title: College Students: School Is Not Your Job
description: To get the maximum value out of those few golden years, treat them like leisure in the truest sense of the word.
content: College freshmen who just arrived on campus have heard, from parents and politicians alike, that college exists mainly for the sake of work. Colleges themselves tout their graduates’ employment rates, starting salaries and career networks as major selling points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Office Race’ Review: Slow and Not So Steady
description: Beck Bennett stars in this funny, familiar Comedy Central sports movie, but Joel McHale steals the show.
content: “Office Race,” a ribald comedy from Jared Lapidus about an inveterate deadbeat reluctantly training for a marathon, understands one of the great unspoken truths about running: that it is a miserable, arduous, soul-destroying pastime, and also deeply, profoundly rewarding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Art Shows and Exhibitions to See This Fall
description: Get ready for “Manet/Degas” and several shows on Picasso this season, plus dazzling surveys of works by Henry Taylor and Alma Thomas.
content: A blockbuster meetup of Manet and Degas, an unprecedented retrospective for Ed Ruscha and a once-in-a-lifetime chance to see an 800-year-old ink painting that has never before left Asia — the new season of museum shows is full of heart-stoppers. A new gallery devoted to plaster is set to open at the Museum of Modern Art, too, and drawing shows are everywhere, from Hanne Darboven in Texas to Stéphane Mandelbaum in New York. A Whitney Museum of American Art show of works on paper by the sculptor Ruth Asawa joins “Drawing the Line: Michelangelo to Asawa,” already open at San Francisco’s Legion of Honor Museum. As always, remember that institutions sometimes change their plans, so please double check times and dates on websites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Invasive Species Are Costing the Global Economy Billions, Study Finds
description: A new scientific report offers the most exhaustive look yet at how nonnative plants and animals can drive extinctions, disrupt food systems and harm human health.
content: Thousands of invasive species introduced to new ecosystems around the world are causing more than $423 billion in estimated losses to the global economy every year by harming nature, damaging food systems and threatening human health, a wide-ranging scientific report published on Monday has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Few Are Trading In Dangerous E-Bikes for Safer Ones, Despite Fire Risk
description: The cost of a trade-in and the logistics of the program have been barriers for delivery workers using older bikes.
content: After a spate of deadly lithium battery fires in New York City, an e-bike trade-in program began to offer brand-new e-bikes certified to industry safety standards at discounted prices to delivery workers who brought in their old ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Changes in Ukraine’s military leadership.
content: Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, said he was replacing his minister of defense, in the biggest shake-up in the leadership of Ukraine’s war effort since Russia’s invasion began. He cited the need for “new approaches” after more than 18 months of conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finn-Olaf Jones, Jack Healy and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Burning Man Attendees Begin to Leave Soggy Festival Site
description: Thousands of people have been stranded for days at the festival’s remote desert site in Nevada because of torrential rain.
content: Thousands of people who had spent days stranded at the Burning Man festival in a rain-gorged stew of mud and slop began to pack up their camps on Monday and stream away from the sprawling site in remote northwest Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: What’s Next for Hurricane Season
description: The potential for hurricanes in the coming months.
content: In a typical Atlantic Ocean hurricane season, August is the ramp-up to September’s peak. This season came to life almost overnight in mid-August, producing a record four named storms in less than 48 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: A Conservative Push to Save Ken Paxton
description: The effort to help the Texas attorney general, whose impeachment trial starts Tuesday, is part of an ongoing struggle over the Republican Party’s future.
content: With television ads and text messages, direct mail and billboards, supporters of the embattled Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, have embarked on an escalating campaign of political pressure, backed by hard-right billionaires, aimed at trying to sway the outcome of Mr. Paxton’s upcoming impeachment trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Telluride Film Festival Goes On, Despite Anxiety Over Strikes
description: The festival opened this weekend with fewer stars, who were wary of breaking union rules about promoting films while two strikes have shut down much of Hollywood.
content: Majestic vistas, burbling brooks and sanguine festival goers are the hallmarks of the Telluride Film Festival, a showcase for the most prestigious films of the year. But no amount of natural beauty can overcome the low-level of anxiety that coursed through this mountain town over Labor Day weekend. With dual strikes raging in Hollywood — the writers’ strike just hit four months — no one wants to appear out of step with these unprecedented times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Faced With Evolving Threats, U.S. Navy Struggles to Change
description: A new generation of cheaper and more flexible vessels could be vital in any conflict with China, but the Navy remains lashed to big shipbuilding programs driven by tradition, political influence and jobs.
content: A symphony of sorts echoed through the sprawling shipyard on the Gulf Coast of Mississippi — banging, hissing, beeping, horns, bells and whistles — as more than 7,000 workers hustled to fill orders fueled by the largest shipbuilding budget in the Navy’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: One Thing Not to Fear at Burning Man
description: There are many causes for concern at the mud-drenched gathering, but human nature isn’t one of them.
content: The news that thousands of Burning Man festivalgoers were told to conserve food and water after torrential rains left them trapped by impassable mud in the Nevada desert led some to chortle about a “Lord of the Flies” scenario for the annual gathering popular with tech lords and moguls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: Dance Performances, Festivals and More Coming This Fall
description: A new season brings exciting works by the likes of (La)Horde collective and Ligia Lewis, as well as classics from New York City Ballet and Alvin Ailey.
content: Anniversary celebrations abound this year, in a dance season that seems conspicuously preoccupied with the past. But in some cases the old is a foundation for the new. Queer adaptations of Ballets Russes classics, a “Rite of Spring” performed by dancers from 14 African countries, a bluegrass version of an Agnes de Mille masterpiece: Artists and companies are pulling history into the present by rethinking, rather than simply revisiting, familiar repertory. (Dates are subject to change; please check websites.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Iga Swiatek, No. 1 Seed at U.S. Open, Loses in Fourth Round
description: Swiatek, the top-ranked woman, lost to Jelena Ostapenko in three sets.
content: When Iga Swiatek, the No. 1 seed at the U.S. Open, took the first set against Jelena Ostapenko on Sunday night, it seemed like business as usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Rishi Sunak, Behind in U.K. Polls, Embraces Divisive Politics
description: Climate. Refugees. Crime. With an election looming next year, the prime minister and his party are turning to populist issues.
content: When Greenpeace activists draped Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s baronial country house in black fabric last month to protest his energy policies, public reaction focused on the troubling lapse in security. But on another level, the stunt showed that Mr. Sunak’s brand of hard-edge politics was hitting home in Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Dodgers’ Julio Urias Arrested on Domestic Violence Felony
description: The star pitcher was charged after a physical altercation on Sunday evening at a soccer stadium in South Los Angeles and later freed on $50,000 bail, the authorities said.
content: The Dodgers pitcher Julio Urias was arrested late Sunday night and charged with a domestic violence felony after a physical altercation with his wife at a stadium in South Los Angeles, the authorities said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Sarah Kerr
title: Soundtrack of a Coup: The Revival of Pro-Military Music in Niger
description: Music videos praising the military have proliferated since generals seized power, highlighting the army’s longstanding importance in Niger and popular dissatisfaction with civilian rule.
content: In one video a famous trio of female artists dressed in fatigues lauds soldiers who they say are as fast as antelopes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Lengel
title: In Detroit, a Tiny Home Generates a Big Controversy
description: A program that rents homes to low-income residents, and helps them build equity as homeowners, was rocked when one of the initial participants was evicted.
content: On Detroit’s west side, near a commercial strip lined with vacant lots, empty shops, storefront churches and motorcycle clubs, sits a cluster of relatively new, micro-size houses — 225 to 470 square feet — residences that look more like seasonal cottages in a resort town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Schultz and Victor Mather
title: A Curtain Call for Racing Season in Upstate New York
description: With summer at an end, fans who enjoy the drama of horse racing at Saratoga must say goodbye for another year.
content: You might think of Saratoga Race Course as a theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Everdeen Mason
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A Strong Job Market Doesn’t Mean the Economy Is Recession-Proof
description: The labor market is more vulnerable than it looks, so the Federal Reserve should tread carefully.
content: Economic growth has weakened considerably, but it’s still relatively easy for people to find jobs. That’s puzzling economists, who are used to seeing job offers disappear when growth slows. In other words, it’s a happy day for labor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Naomi Klein, Naomi Wolf and the Political Upside Down
description: “Doppelganger” is a brilliant examination of a berserk political moment.
content: I’ve been raving about Naomi Klein’s “Doppelganger” since I read an advance copy this summer, and when I tell people about it, some of them are baffled: You mean Klein wrote a whole book about being confused with the writer Naomi Wolf? The central conceit of “Doppelganger” sounds more like the premise for a surreal Charlie Kaufman film than a work by an earnest lefty who usually writes about overweening corporate power. Klein herself is apologetic about it. “In my defense, it was never my intent to write this book,” she says in its first line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye and Hiroko Masuike
title: Back to New Jersey, Where the Universe Began
description: A half-century ago, a radio telescope in Holmdel, N.J., sent two astronomers 13.8 billion years back in time — and opened a cosmic window that scientists have been peering through ever since.
content: On a field just below the summit of Crawford Hill, the highest point in Monmouth County, N.J., almost within sight of the skyscrapers of Manhattan, sits a cluster of shacks and sheds. Next to them is the Holmdel Horn Antenna, a radio telescope somewhat resembling the scoop of a giant steam shovel: an aluminum box 20 feet square at the mouth and tapering to an eight-inch opening, through which the radio waves are funneled into the “cab,” a wooden hut on stilts. From a distance, the whole site could be mistaken for an old mining camp you might come across in Montana or Idaho.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Is Burning Man, and Why Have Paris Hilton and Elon Musk Shown Up?
description: The annual festival started as an impromptu bonfire, but now attracts tens of thousands of revelers a year. How did it get here?
content: “Imagine a hallucinogenic state fair,” the reporter Rick Marin wrote about Burning Man in The New York Times in 2000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Urban Animals Can’t Take the Heat, Study Finds
description: A warming climate could make cities even less hospitable to wild mammals, according to new research.
content: Don’t let the rats fool you. Although the pizza-pilfering vagabonds — and a variety of other creatures — thrive in cities, for many wild animals urban environments are unappealing homes, covered in concrete and carved up by car traffic. As buildings go up and roads are laid down, some species seem to vanish from the landscape, and animal communities often become less diverse, scientists have found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Rapley
title: America Is an Empire in Decline. That Doesn’t Mean It Has to Fall.
description: The Roman Empire is both an illuminating precedent and a cautionary tale.
content: America likes to think of itself in garlanded terms. The shining city on a hill. The indispensable nation. The land of the free. There’s something to each sobriquet, to be sure. But there’s another phrase, not always so flattering, that also applies to the United States: global empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Ben Sisario
title: Steve Harwell, Voice of the Band Smash Mouth, Is Dead at 56
description: He was a founding member of the band, which broke out in the late 1990s with hit songs like “Walkin’ on the Sun” and “All Star.”
content: Steve Harwell, the former lead singer of the rock band Smash Mouth, which was best known for its 1999 hit “All Star,” died on Monday. He was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley Has a Playbook for Winning Tough Races, but 2024 Is Different
description: Still pitching herself as a political outsider, Ms. Haley now has a political résumé that includes a stint in the Trump administration. Then there’s Mr. Trump himself.
content: Nikki Haley was polling in the low digits, fighting for oxygen among better-known and better-funded rivals in a contest clouded by scandal and involving the man whose job they all sought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In U.K. Crisis Over Unsafe Schools, Ex-Official Pins Blame on Sunak
description: The prime minister was warned in his past job as finance chief, an official said, that hundreds of schools contained dangerously weak concrete. Now classrooms are having to shut.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faced a mounting crisis over Britain’s crumbling schools after a former government official said on Monday that Mr. Sunak had refused to rebuild more schools while he was head of the Treasury, despite warnings that lightweight concrete used in hundreds of buildings was a risk to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Marilyn Lovell, Astronaut’s Wife in the Spotlight, Is Dead at 93
description: She embodied the glamour and the hardship of being married to an American hero. Her husband, Jim Lovell, was the captain of the ill-fated Apollo 13 mission in 1970.
content: Marilyn Lovell, who, as an object of fascination for the news media, the inspiration for movie and TV characters and a figure in history books, incarnated for many Americans the hardships and glamour of being an astronaut’s wife, died on Aug. 27 in Lake Forest, Ill. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Hawthorne
title: Architecture’s Second Looks, and Second Acts
description: From Lower Manhattan to Crenshaw Boulevard, Zaha Hadid to Belgian Art Nouveau, this fall brings reappraisals of buildings, sites, streets, design movements and architects that we thought we knew.
content: In 2006, Joshua Ramus, a 36-year-old protégé of the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, left Koolhaas’s hugely influential firm, Office for Metropolitan Architecture, to go off on his own. In the kind of power play more typical of Hollywood talent agencies than architecture studios, he also took O.M.A.’s entire 35-person New York office with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: How Smash Mouth’s ‘All Star’ Got a Second Wind From Memes
description: The track, sung by Steve Harwell, took a winding path to evergreen status that illustrates how social media and fan-made content have transformed the music business.
content: Long before it became a soundtrack nugget and an internet meme, it was just a rock band’s attempt to land a radio hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: A Painting Looted at Least Once, From Hitler, Is on the Block
description: Some experts believe this 17th-century work now up for sale was originally stolen by the Nazis, but no clues to its prewar owner have turned up in years of searching.
content: It has become a familiar scenario in the art world: the heirs of a Jewish collector spot a painting in an auction catalog that was stolen from their relative in the Nazi era. They contact the auction house and, if all goes well, reach a settlement with the seller that ensures they receive a share of the revenue from the sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Tuesday Briefing: Kim and Putin Plan to Meet in Russia
description: Also, Xi Jinping might skip the Group of 20 summit.
content: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, plans to travel to Russia this month to meet with its president, Vladimir Putin, to discuss military cooperation, including the possibility of supplying Russia with more weaponry for its war in Ukraine, according to U.S. and allied officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaj Larsen
title: Will Tensions With China Suck the Fun Out of American Movies?
description: A proposed amendment to the National Defense Authorization Act is against U.S. interests at home and abroad.
content: Two summers ago, I rode in a combat rubber raiding craft — a Zodiac — with two fellow Navy SEALs and an Air Force pararescueman. We moved quietly through the water, our M4s in hand and our objective in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Douglas Lenat, Who Tried to Make A.I. More Human, Dies at 72
description: He spent decades working on artificial intelligence, striving to create computers that could replicate common sense.
content: Douglas Lenat, an artificial intelligence researcher who spent nearly 40 years trying to build common sense into computers, recreating human judgment one logical rule at a time, died on Thursday in Austin, Texas. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caren Osten Gerszberg
title: Latest in Wellness Travel: The Menopause Retreat
description: A growing number of spas and resorts are offering programs that target the changes of perimenopause and menopause. The biggest benefit may be the chance to bond with other women going through the same thing.
content: With a growing number of women approaching the age of hormonal changes — by 2025, approximately 1.1 billion women worldwide will have experienced menopause — the travel industry is catering to a new niche: Women who want help dealing with everything from hot flashes to mood swings, with perhaps some classic spa treatments thrown in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Over 100 Connecticut State Troopers Accused of Faking Traffic Stops
description: Auditors found tens of thousands of apparently falsified traffic stop records, many of white drivers. They suspect the officers were trying to appear more productive.
content: On an unseasonably warm morning in February 2017, a 75-year-old white motorist was making his way north on Interstate 95 in Westbrook, Conn., when he was pulled over by a state trooper and charged with a traffic violation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern house in Los Angeles, a Craftsman bungalow in Sacramento and a three-bedroom townhouse in Mountain View.
content: This Woodland Hills house was designed by Charles Du Bois, a prolific local architect who worked as a set designer for MGM early in his career. It was recently renovated and has new electrical and plumbing systems; new interior and exterior lighting; and new windows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Minx’ and ‘Office Race’
description: The cheeky Starz show wraps up its second season, and Comedy Central premieres an original film.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Sept. 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason M. Bailey
title: 12 Video Games Releasing This Fall
description: Mortal Kombat, Super Mario Bros. and more are coming this season.
content: It has been such a fruitful year for video games that you couldn’t blame someone for wanting a light fall lineup to finish titles like Tears of the Kingdom and Baldur’s Gate 3. For better or worse, this season is stacked with AAA releases, long-awaited sequels and promising independent games. (Some games will be available before their official launch dates because of early-access programs.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Land Art Today, Beyond Cowboys With Bulldozers
description: The vast, misunderstood field of land art will be revisited this fall in a historical survey and new projects on farms and within city limits.
content: I’m standing in a fallow field on the edge of the San Luis Valley, in south-central Colorado. To the east, beyond a windbreak of tough old trees, the Great Sand Dunes rise against the mountains, where for millenniums this same wind has piled up this same sandy soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A Young Player’s Future Looks Bright Until He Runs Into Carlos Alcaraz
description: Unseeded Matteo Arnaldi rolled into the fourth round at the U.S. Open, but that’s where his terrific run ended.
content: Matteo Arnaldi, an unheralded Italian player, was having a lovely time in New York, knocking off one opponent after another on his way to the fourth round at the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ben Shelton and Frances Tiafoe Set for All-American Quarterfinal
description: Here’s what to know about the singles match between Shelton and Tiafoe, two of the three American men remaining in the U.S. Open.
content: The men’s semifinals at the U.S. Open are guaranteed to include at least one American.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: American Lives Forever Changed by a Weapon Being Sent to Ukraine
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 5, 2023.
content: “If a Marine dies of enemy fire, you can direct that anger at the enemy. If it’s friendly ordnance, who do you direct that anger to?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Have You Seen Paul McCartney’s Lost Bass Guitar? Tips Welcome.
description: For decades, mystery has surrounded the fate of the missing bass that accompanied the Beatles as they rocketed to fame. A new campaign is trying to find it.
content: Before Beatlemania, there was the distinctive Höfner violin bass — the first guitar that Paul McCartney bought after becoming the bassist for the Beatles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Perilous, Icy Mission Rescues Sick Worker in Antarctica
description: It took an icebreaker ship and two long-range helicopters to evacuate the staff member from an Australian research base to advanced medical care.
content: When a staff member fell ill at Australia’s Antarctic research station and couldn’t be treated locally, the team tasked with rescuing them faced a daunting endeavor rife with obstacles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Occupational Segregation Drives Persistent Inequality, Study Says
description: New research points to the limits of education as a path to upward mobility for Black workers.
content: Education has long been hailed as the path to upward mobility in America. But new research points to limits of education as an economic escalator for Black workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: The Ground-Floor Window Into What’s Ailing Downtowns
description: City centers may have to be reimagined to solve the problem of vacant storefronts.
content: Downtown San Francisco’s office buildings have been quieted by some of the highest vacancy rates and slowest return-to-office trends in the country. But when walking around the area, what makes it feel still so uninhabited is a different but related phenomenon downstairs from all those empty offices: the vacant ground floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: China’s Biggest Homebuilder Reels as Economy Slows
description: Once considered a survivor of China’s real estate turmoil, Country Garden is now at the center of the crisis and threatens the broader economy.
content: When Country Garden, the biggest developer in China’s increasingly troubled real estate sector, published its annual report in April, the cover design exuded hope: a phoenix spreading its wings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Nate Schweber
title: Brooklyn Waves Goodbye to Summer in a Whirl of Feathers and Flags
description: People filled Eastern Parkway to celebrate Caribbean culture at the annual J’Ouvert celebration and the West Indian American Day Parade.
content: A rainbow crested over Brooklyn early on Monday morning as revelers gathered to send off the summer in the annual J’Ouvert celebration, and then march down Eastern Parkway in a whirl of flags and feathers in the city’s West Indian American Day parade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Priscilla Presley’s Emotional Reaction to Sofia Coppola’s New Elvis Film
description: The story of her life with the rock star lacks major musical moments because the singer’s estate wouldn’t support the warts-and-all treatment.
content: You may not think there’s a need for two big Elvis Presley movies in back-to-back years, but it’s hard to imagine a pair of filmmakers with sensibilities as different as Baz Luhrmann, who directed “Elvis” (2022), and Sofia Coppola, who came to the Venice Film Festival on Monday to debut “Priscilla,” about the rocky marriage between Priscilla Presley and her famous beau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine’s Arrest of Powerful Oligarch Is Latest Sign of Anti-Corruption Efforts
description: The detention of Ihor Kolomoisky came as Ukraine steps up efforts to punish graft and make its case for closer integration with the European Union.
content: The arrest over the weekend of Ihor Kolomoisky, one of Ukraine’s richest men, has been seen as a sign of Ukrainian authorities’ drive to root out corruption and curb the influence of oligarchs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: How a Gay Republican Sees the Rise in Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Rhetoric on the Right
description: Amid an uptick in anti-gay rhetoric, Jane Coaston interviews Brad Polumbo, a gay Republican-leaning podcaster, about what’s happening on the right.
content: When I talked to the political commentator Brad Polumbo, he told me that he wished America could go back to the L.G.B.T.Q. politics of a few years ago, which he sees as a time of “détente” on gay rights issues among conservatives. Mr. Polumbo is a podcaster who leans Republican, and he is gay. In his view, his sexual orientation didn’t matter much to conservatives during the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Official From Sweden Imprisoned in Iran for Over 500 Days
description: The case of Johan Floderus, kept under wraps for more than a year, has become part of Iran’s “hostage diplomacy” as Tehran seeks concessions from the West.
content: A Swedish citizen working for the European Union diplomatic corps has been imprisoned in Iran for more than 500 days, making him an important bargaining chip for Tehran as it tries to wring concessions from the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Lea Michele Ends ‘Dream’ Run in ‘Funny Girl’ After Reinvigorating Show
description: The Broadway revival saw an immediate change in its fortunes when the actress stepped into the production last September.
content: “That was my dream come true,” Lea Michele gushed from the stage on Sunday after her final performance in “Funny Girl,” the Broadway revival that the actress breathed new life into when its future looked grim one year ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman and Michael Tyrone Delaney
title: At 97, the First Lady of Fitness Is Still Shaping the Industry
description: Elaine LaLanne — who revolutionized modern exercise alongside her husband, Jack — is a model for aging well.
content: Elaine LaLanne’s morning exercises often begin before she’s even out of bed. Lying on top of the covers, she does two-dozen jackknifes. At the bathroom sink, she does incline push-ups. After she dresses and applies her makeup, she heads to her home gym, where she walks uphill on a treadmill for a few minutes and does lat pull-downs on a machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Sameer Yasir
title: China’s Leader Looks Set to Skip G20 Summit in Snub to India
description: Xi Jinping has never missed the annual Group of 20 gathering since taking power in 2012. Beijing would not explain his apparent decision to forgo the event in New Delhi.
content: China indicated on Monday that its top leader, Xi Jinping, would skip the Group of 20 summit meeting in New Delhi this weekend, dealing a blow to India, the event’s host nation, and raising questions about Mr. Xi’s profile as a global statesman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Larry McMurtry, a Critter of the American West Who Rejected Its Mythos
description: Tracy Daugherty’s new biography is the first comprehensive account of the prolific novelist who brought us “Lonesome Dove,” “The Last Picture Show” and more.
content: When the art critic Dave Hickey learned that Tracy Daugherty was writing a biography of his friend Larry McMurtry (all three men are Texans), he said to Daugherty: “Knowing Larry, it’s going to be a real episodic book.” Episodic this biography is. It’s also vastly entertaining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: Clean Energy Projects Are Booming Everywhere. Except in Poor Nations.
description: A big obstacle is the lack of loans, a subject of intense disagreement between richer and poorer countries. But in Congo, a hard-fought solar investment shows a possible path forward.
content: The world is racing ahead with enormous investments in renewable energy, for the first time this year plowing more money into solar power than oil.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Where in the World Are People Back in the Office?
description: A city’s density, the size of people’s homes and cultural norms are among the factors that affect hybrid work patterns.
content: In London, a politician wrote not-so-subtle notes to remote workers last year, hoping to persuade them to spend more time in the office: “Sorry you were out when I visited,” Jacob Rees-Mogg, then a government minister, recalled writing in messages left on the desks of Cabinet Office staff members who were working from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Jimmy Buffett Died of Rare Form of Skin Cancer
description: The singer’s website said he had Merkel cell carcinoma for four years and died at his home on Long Island.
content: Jimmy Buffett died of skin cancer at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y., on Long Island, according to a statement on the singer-songwriter’s website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: No Sweat. Frances Tiafoe Would Like a Fresh Shirt Now.
description: Many athletes take their quirks and superstitions with them into competition, but Tiafoe has taken changing his damp shirt midmatch to an unusual level.
content: During a changeover 26 minutes into his second-round match against Sebastian Ofner, Frances Tiafoe reached into his bag, pulled out a fresh top and changed his shirt. Twenty-four minutes later, up by 4-1 in the second set, he swapped that shirt for a clean one again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Chace
title: Edith Grossman, Who Elevated the Art of Translation, Dies at 87
description: “You are my voice in English,” Gabriel García Márquez told her. She insisted that her name appear on the covers of books she translated, including with that of Cervantes.
content: Edith Grossman, whose acclaimed translations of “Love in the Time of Cholera” by Gabriel García Márquez and “Don Quixote” by Miguel de Cervantes raised the profile of the often-overlooked role of the translator, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: A New Energy Is Vibrating at This House
description: Under the leadership of Bonaventure Soh Bejeng Ndikung, Berlin’s once dowdy House of World Cultures now throbs with D.J. sets and transformative ideas.
content: On a bright morning in early June, German lawmakers, Berlin city officials, ambassadors and other dignitaries clustered at the door of a hulking Modernist edifice, waiting for a Vodou priest to conclude a ritual under a tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Baked Spaghetti Is a 9x13 Pan of Comfort
description: And a six-ingredient, 20-minute, five-star salmon recipe that one reader calls “life-changing.”
content: Hello! Mia again, here with you for one more Cooking newsletter adventure before Melissa returns on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I Put My Money on the Weeping Mothers at the Tennessee State Capitol
description: Our state’s Republican supermajority has again done nothing in the face of the slaughter of our children.
content: “No Significant Action Taken on TN Gun Laws” read the headline of The Tennessean on Wednesday, the day after the Tennessee General Assembly ended a special legislative session on gun safety. To call that headline an understatement is itself an understatement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Are You Ever Too Old to Wear Vintage?
description: A reader wonders how to wear retro pieces without looking dated.
content: It is true that when we think about vintage clothing these days, we often think about it as a young person’s game: Gen Z rediscovering the ’90s (or the ’80s or the early 2000s) and finding the joy in low-slung cargo pants, cropped tops and mini backpacks as everyone celebrates them as champions of sustainability; or fresh-faced celebrities looking hip in midcentury haute couture.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Plus-Size Female Shoppers ‘Deserve Better’
description: Women urge retailers to better meet the needs and tastes of a range of customers. Also: Trump supporters; ChatGPT plagiarism; China’s economic woes; the value of college.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: The Folk Implosion’s Music From ‘Kids’ Is Returning. The Band Is, Too.
description: Lou Barlow and John Davis made tracks for the 1995 cultural flashpoint. They split after a 1999 LP, but reunited during the pandemic, and made plans to release more songs.
content: By the early 1990s, Lou Barlow was used to getting some weird fan mail. The lyrics he wrote for his band Sebadoh seemed to excavate the loneliest and weirdest secrets of his inner world — subject matter that invited Barlow’s listeners to form an unusually close relationship to its singer. He didn’t think much of it when one of those fans, a teenager named Harmony Korine, sent him the full-length script for a pretty out-there movie he’d written called “Kids.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lincoln Michel
title: Will A.I. Change Art? A New Novel Uses A.I. to Explore Just That.
description: Sean Michaels’s “Do You Remember Being Born?,” about a poet who is asked to collaborate with an A.I., explores the dangers and opportunities of incorporating technology into art.
content: At 75 years old, Marian Ffarmer has acquired everything a poet might dream of: a lengthy bibliography, a Pulitzer Prize, an international reputation. Everything except money. “No poet has savings unless they are born to wealth,” she observes. This fact weighs on her now that her son, Courtney, needs cash for a down payment on a house. As she’s despairing, a large tech company writes with a strange offer: Collaborate on a poem with Charlotte, an A.I. writing program, in exchange for a large chunk of cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of Aug. 28, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hive mind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
title: Kim Jong-un and Putin Plan to Meet in Russia to Discuss Weapons
description: Russia seeks more weaponry for its war in Ukraine, and a North Korean delegation recently traveled to Russia by train to plan for Mr. Kim’s visit this month, officials say.
content: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, plans to travel to Russia this month to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin to discuss the possibility of supplying Russia with more weaponry for its war in Ukraine and other military cooperation, according to American and allied officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Daily Blackouts Strain a Poor Spanish Neighborhood. Is Marijuana to Blame?
description: Spain’s largest electricity company says daily power outages are caused by illegal indoor marijuana farms that overload the grid. “Easy excuse,” residents reply.
content: On a recent morning, Ángel Ortiz Rodríguez was slumped on a sofa in his apartment in Granada, in southern Spain, a tangle of breathing tubes protruding from his nose. Since Mr. Ortiz had a heart attack a few years ago, his life has depended on an electronic breathing machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Julian E. Barnes
title: Top Russian General Detained After Wagner Mutiny Is Released
description: Gen. Sergei Surovikin, who was seen as an ally of the mercenary leader Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, has re-emerged in public.
content: A top Russian general detained in the aftermath of the mutiny by the mercenary tycoon Yevgeny V. Prigozhin has been released, according to two U.S. officials and a person close to the Russian Defense Ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: From Mississippi to Bahrain to See the Future of the Navy
description: An investigation into the Navy’s efforts to modernize — to better prepare for a potential conflict with China — took me on a long journey from Pascagoula, Miss., to the Middle East.
content: An investigation into the Navy’s efforts to modernize — to better prepare for a potential conflict with China — took me on a long journey from Pascagoula, Miss., to the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Find These 14 Hidden Children’s Book Titles?
description: Looking for a new way to discover books? More than a dozen titles are hidden within this short section of text and the reading list grows as you correctly click on each one.
content: Looking for a new way to discover books? More than a dozen titles are hidden within this short section of text and the reading list grows as you correctly click on each one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: The Politics of Disasters
description: How candidates and office-holders have navigated hurricanes and other crises.
content: How candidates and office-holders have navigated hurricanes and other crises.
source.name: The New York Times
